paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium balance evaluation in long-term field experiments under different fertilization treatments with focus on K recovery rates and soil K pools

research_methodology.experimental_design: Long-term stationary field experiments with 6 fertilization treatments in 3-crop rotation system, established in 1996, with annual crop production and 4 replications

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Annual yield and plant K content measurements; soil sampling at establishment (1996) and end of 7th rotation (2017)
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Full growing season for all crops with specific application timings: autumn (organic/mineral P/K), spring (mineral N)
monitoring_timeline: 1996: Experiment establishment and initial soil characterization
1996-2017: Annual yield measurements and plant K content analysis
2017: Final soil sampling after plant harvest (end of 7th rotation cycle)
Continuous: Weather and climate data collection

spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: Two contrasting soil-climatic regions in Czech Republic
site_characteristics: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol on loess, clay loam texture, 265 m elevation
Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss, sandy loam texture, 525 m elevation
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Representative of intensive farming systems in Czech Republic

sample_sizes.plant_samples: Annual sampling from all treatments and replications

sample_design.replication_levels: 4 replications for soil and plant analyses
sample_design.randomization_approach: Randomized complete block design (implied by experimental structure)
controls_and_treatments: FYM 1: Full dose farmyard manure (330 kg N/ha/3-year cycle)
FYM 1/2: Half dose farmyard manure + mineral N (165 kg N from FYM + 165 kg mineral N)
N: Mineral nitrogen only (330 kg N/ha/3-year cycle)
NPK: Mineral NPK fertilization (330 kg N + 90 kg P + 270 kg K/ha/3-year cycle)
N + St: Mineral N + spring barley straw incorporation
sample_design.statistical_power: Not explicitly calculated but adequate for detecting treatment differences

measurement_protocols: Plant K analysis: Dry decomposition (Mader et al. 1998) followed by atomic absorption spectrometry (AA280FS)
Soil bioavailable K: CaCl2/DTPA (CAT) extraction (CSN EN 13651, 2001)
Soil Mehlich-3 extractable K: Multi-element extraction (Mehlich 1984)
Soil exchangeable K: 1 mol/L ammonium acetate extraction (modified Haby et al. 1990)
Soil non-exchangeable K: Boiling 1 mol/L HNO3 extraction (Helmke and Sparks 2000)
instrumentation: Atomic Absorption Spectrometer (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies, Mulgrave, Australia)
quality_control: Standardized extraction protocols following international standards
Air-dried soil samples sieved to ≤2 mm
Consistent sample preparation (3.0 g soil, specific solution ratios)

detection_limits.not_explicitly_stated: Detection limits not provided in paper

statistical_approach.significance_testing: P < 0.001 reported for correlations; general significance testing applied
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Standard error calculations implied but not explicitly reported
statistical_approach.model_validation: Regression models validated with R² values reported

primary_measurements.parameter: K recovery rate from farmyard manure
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Overall recovery across both sites over 21 years

primary_measurements.parameter: K recovery rate from mineral NPK fertilizers
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Overall recovery across both sites over 21 years
Mineral N treatment at Humpolec site

statistical_relationships.relationship_type: Soil sorption capacity and K utilization
statistical_relationships.effect_size: Higher utilization in soils with higher sorption capacity

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Decreasing trend in all unfertilized treatments; maintenance or increase only with adequate K fertilization
Significant depletion at Luvisol site (Hněvčeves) but not at Cambisol site (Humpolec)
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: Not applicable - measured at start and end

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Consistently negative balances for most treatments over 21 years, positive only for full manure treatment

comparative_results.practical_significance: Despite lower soil K, higher plant uptake due to climate and potato yields

comparative_results.comparison_type: Fertilization treatment effects on K balance
comparative_results.practical_significance: Only full manure treatment maintained positive balance
Mineral fertilizers generally more efficient but site-dependent
Fundamental difference in soil K supplying capacity

geographic_details.elevation: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.
geographic_details.landscape_position: Hněvčeves: lowland position; Humpolec: upland position

precipitation_patterns.distribution_quality: Regular distribution throughout vegetation period at Humpolec

climate_characteristics.growing_season: Defined by 3-crop rotation cycle with autumn and spring applications

soil_properties.soil_classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol on loess; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam (4.4% clay, 77.0% silt, 18.7% sand); Humpolec: Sandy loam (5.8% clay, 43.6% silt, 50.6% sand)
soil_properties.mineralogy: 2:1 clay minerals (mica, vermiculite) important for K fixation; paragneiss parent material releases K through weathering at Humpolec

land_use_context.management_intensity: High intensity with regular fertilization and annual cropping
land_use_context.historical_context: Long-term experimental plots established 1996, representing 21 years of consistent management

timing: Organic fertilizers (FYM, straw): Autumn (October) to potatoes
Mineral P and K: Autumn to each crop
Mineral N: Spring to potatoes and barley
Mineral N to wheat: Split application at BBCH 21 and BBCH 31-32

other_practices.tillage: Conventional tillage system (specific details not provided)
rotation: 3-year rotation: potatoes → winter wheat → spring barley

study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Annual for crops, specific time points for soil

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Autumn applications (organic, P, K) and spring applications (mineral N)
Accumulation during growing season, maximum at harvest

long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Soil K depletion threatens long-term productivity
Only full manure treatment sustainable long-term

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Stable at Humpolec, decreasing at Hněvčeves
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Site-specific K supplying capacity affects sustainability

inter_annual_variability.yield_variability: Annual yield variations impact K removal

spatial_variability.between_sites: Fundamental differences in soil K supplying capacity

measurement_uncertainty.analytical_precision: High correlation between methods indicates precision

methodological_strengths: Exceptional long-term duration (21 years) provides robust trend analysis
Two contrasting sites enhance generalizability and understanding of soil-specific effects
Comprehensive K extraction methods (4 different approaches) provide complete picture of soil K pools
Detailed balance calculations with precise input/output tracking
Adequate replication (4 reps) for statistical analysis
Representative crop rotation system matching regional agriculture
Standardized analytical methods following international protocols
Strong correlation between extraction methods validates analytical precision
methodological_limitations: Final soil samples (2017) taken only from spring barley plots - may not represent full rotation effects
Specific replication numbers for plant analyses not explicitly stated
Statistical significance levels not consistently reported with exact p-values
Seasonal soil K dynamics not captured - only start/end measurements
Weather data mentioned but not detailed in results
No assessment of subsoil K contributions to plant uptake
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: Very high - comprehensive balance calculations, multiple soil K pools, detailed yield and plant K data

measurement_precision.analytical_precision: High - demonstrated by strong correlations between methods
measurement_precision.field_precision: Good - replicated sampling and standardized protocols

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Good - two sites representing different soil-climate conditions in Czech Republic
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Excellent - 21 years captures long-term trends and variability
representativeness.system_representativeness: Very good - crop rotation and intensification typical of Czech agriculture

uncertainty_sources: Inter-annual weather variability effects on K uptake
Potential incomplete sampling of soil K pools (subsoil not assessed)
Temporal gaps in soil K measurements (only 2 time points)
Analytical uncertainty in K measurements (though minimized by method validation)
validation_evidence: Strong correlations between different K extraction methods
Consistent results with previous literature (Blake et al. 1999)
Logical relationships between soil properties and K dynamics
Replicated results across two contrasting sites

key_methodological_references: Egnér et al. (1960) - Historical K extraction methods
Blake et al. (1999) - Long-term K balance studies
Haby et al. (1990) - Ammonium acetate extraction
Helmke and Sparks (2000) - Boiling HNO3 extraction
Mader et al. (1998) - Plant analysis methods
Hinsinger and Jaillard (1993) - Root-induced K release
Steingrobe and Claasen (2000) - Rhizosphere K dynamics
comparative_studies: Blake et al. (1999) - European long-term K balance studies
Srinivasarao et al. (2014) - Long-term K dynamics in India
Liu et al. (2010) - Fertilization effects on soil K
Øgaard and Krogstad (2005) - Soil K extraction methods
Kitagawa et al. (2018) - Non-exchangeable K assessment
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Soil K dynamics including exchangeable/non-exchangeable pools, plant uptake mechanisms, fertilizer K utilization, and long-term balance calculations
data_sources: Annual crop yield and composition data
benchmarking_data: K utilization rates compared to Blake et al. (1999)
Soil K pool sizes compared to international studies
K balance calculations referenced to other long-term studies
validation_studies: Consistency with soil K theory and previous research

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: Exceptionally rich - comprehensive quantitative data on all aspects of K cycling including inputs, outputs, soil pools, and plant uptake across treatments and sites
potential_ambiguities: Replication numbers for plant analyses not explicitly stated
Exact timing of soil sampling in 2017 (only stated as 'after harvest')
Specific weather conditions during study period not detailed
Statistical significance levels not consistently reported
extraction_limitations: Table data mentioned but not provided in source text
Figure data referenced but numerical values not all extractable from text
Some methodological details abbreviated in paper format
recommended_validation_checks: Review original paper tables for additional precision
Cross-reference with related publications from same experiment
Verify extraction method correlations with original data

human_extraction_notes.extraction_approach: Manual comprehensive extraction following Stage 1A prompt exactly
additional_insights: Critical finding: Only full manure treatment maintained positive K balance
Soil-specific differences in K supplying capacity fundamental to sustainability
Higher K utilization efficiency in mineral vs organic fertilizers but site-dependent
Non-exchangeable K pool size determines site vulnerability to K depletion
areas_requiring_attention: Long-term sustainability implications of negative K balances
Soil-specific fertilizer recommendations based on K supplying capacity
Economic implications of different fertilization strategies
Environmental impacts of K depletion vs excess application
human_extraction_notes.scientific_significance: Demonstrates critical importance of soil-specific K management for sustainable agriculture and reveals inadequacy of current mineral fertilizer K rates
